title: Arup, USGBC California launch comprehensive rebuilding guide for California wildfire victims
author: Josh Niland
excerpt: Arup, in collaboration with the California chapter of the U.S. Green Building Council (USGBC-CA), has released a guide to rebuilding for homeowners impacted by the Los Angeles Fires. The 65-page guidance includes recommendations for building back safely and sustainably while reducing costs...
text: anchor Image: CAL FIRE_Official/Flickr (CC BY-NC 2.0) Arup, in collaboration with the California chapter of the U.S. Green Building Council (USGBC-CA), has released a guide to rebuilding for homeowners impacted by the Los Angeles Fires.  The 65-page guidance includes recommendations for building back safely and sustainably while reducing costs and is aimed at equipping stakeholders to pursue more equitable, climate-resilient rebuilding solutions across the state—which has lost at least 39,000 properties to damage in the last five years. The information included allows for a decision matrix to be established using recommendations for everything related to building systems/envelopes, landscaping, roofs, exterior walls, windows, ventilation, a new building’s placement, and more. Related on Archinect: Urban Land Institute, USC, and UCLA release post-wildfire rebuilding roadmap for L.A.An FAQ section is included to answer questions hanging over the individual recovery "journey" and equip those affected with the proper tools and resources to make meaningful/informed decisions as they move forward. Designers and building contractors may also use the guide for inspiration and other assurances that will help them enhance the safety of their clients and the communities they are connected to.  The USGBC-CA guide offers more than other comparable ones that are recently available, leveraging data from the Insurance Institute for Business & Home Safety (IBHS) and other entities in a way that couples cost efficiency with community-based solutions and the threats from other natural disasters. Its authors say it is particularly well-tailored to those in Southern California. This adds to a list of post-fire recovery resources produced by UCLA, the Urban Land Institute, and USC and the AIA Pasadena & Foothill chapter.     Image: CAL FIRE_Official/Flickr (CC BY-NC 2.0)

    Arup, in collaboration with the California chapter of the U.S. Green Building Council (USGBC-CA), has released a guide to rebuilding for homeowners impacted by the Los Angeles Fires. 

    The 65-page guidance includes recommendations for building back safely and sustainably while reducing costs and is aimed at equipping stakeholders to pursue more equitable, climate-resilient rebuilding solutions across the state—which has lost at least 39,000 properties to damage in the last five years.

    The information included allows for a decision matrix to be established using recommendations for everything related to building systems/envelopes, landscaping, roofs, exterior walls, windows, ventilation, a new building’s placement, and more.

    An FAQ section is included to answer questions hanging over the individual recovery "journey" and equip those affected with the proper tools and resources to make meaningful/informed decisions as they move forward.

    Designers and building contractors may also use the guide for inspiration and other assurances that will help them enhance the safety of their clients and the communities they are connected to. 

    The USGBC-CA guide offers more than other comparable ones that are recently available, leveraging data from the Insurance Institute for Business & Home Safety (IBHS) and other entities in a way that couples cost efficiency with community-based solutions and the threats from other natural disasters. Its authors say it is particularly well-tailored to those in Southern California.

    This adds to a list of post-fire recovery resources produced by UCLA, the Urban Land Institute, and USC and the AIA Pasadena & Foothill chapter. More of our coverage concerning the rebuilding effort underway in Los Angeles can be found below:
